A few facts about the metric system:

1. It was essentially developed by the French.
2. The French were annoyed by the British system of units that made no sense to them (and many others).
3. The British units (yard, foot, inch, pound, ounce, gallon, quart, pint etc.) were objected to on the basis of some of them were derived from some British king's decisions and other seemingly arbitrary choices. But, most were officially defined from traditional units (which people had worked out through hands-on usage) based on merchants' and buyers' pleas to their British monarch to make royal pronouncements on the definitions of the various measures used in buying, pricing and selling. In other words, to set legally enforceable standards of units of measurement.
4. It made more sense to the French that the units of measurement should be based on something associated with the planet Earth (Gaia worship?). Never mind that this led to orphan units of measurement that practically no one uses because there are not human-factored uses for them like there is for inch and foot for instance. E.g. dekameter and decimeter.
5. The French also thought that various units should be multiples of 10 where appropriate, so as to obtain easily relatable larger and smaller units. E.g. a housewife would not need to deal with tonne units of butter whereas an exporter might.
6. To determine the metric unit of length, it was decided to perform an on-foot survey of a portion of the globe. A land survey from Barcelona, Spain to Dunkirk in northern France was conducted by a crew led by Jean Delambre and Pierre Mechain. It took six years, partially due to wars etc. and at least one life was lost. Crossing mountains can be dangerous. The idea was to determine the distance of a meridional quadrant of the Earth, the one passing through Paris, and take one ten-millionth part of that to be the definition of the new metre of linear measurement. Assumption were: the Earth is a perfect sphere, the North Star perfectly defines the location of the North Pole, and any number of others. (I'm not entirely sure of the North Star one; maybe they knew how to compensate for the offset.)
7. So, the metre turned out to be somewhere around 39.4 inches, or a little bit longer than a British yard. They could have had the yard for nothing and it was practically the same. Definition of insanity anyone?

Let me be the proud defender of Fahrenheit. Here are the ways in which the Fahrenheit system is superior. The actual degree of a Fahrenheit is smaller, therefore more accurate. Celsius also has a smaller range of values in which humans interact with on Earth. Depending on where one lives, it may only be about 60 degrees between the minimum and maximum, so in a way, Fahrenheit is like being a painter with more colors at their disposal in which to describe the world. You can also say things like "it will be in the low 70s today" which you can't do with celsius because "the low 20s" is too wide of a range of temperatures to be useful. When it comes to doing science, yes, Celsius is better. But just for everyday use and talking about the weather, I genuinely believe the Fahrenheit system to be superior. For those of us in the Western world, we often interact with temperatures ranging from -20F to 130F (min-max) or for me in the Midwest, typically closer to 0F-100F. Unless one is in a field of work where they are boiling water all the time, 100 degrees being the "maximum temperature that I might feel in a summer" is far more useful than 100 degrees being the temperature at which water boils. So what if 212 degrees seems arbitrary? How often does one actually interact with this boiling point? Not very often. We throw the kettle on and go about our day, so who cares if that number is 212 or 100? I'm an American who lived in Canada for 4 years and I have to say that after interacting with both Fahrenheit and Celsius, I absolutely preferred Fahrenheit because it seems more tuned to everyday life.

As a Canadian, you interact with Fahrenheit all the time. Your temperature at the hospital is typically taken in F. When you use a stove, it is in F. Canada uses a hybrid mix-mash of systems much like the United States. I think that being familiar with both systems is the way to go. When it comes to metric vs English systems as a whole. Who cares about Km vs Miles? Or Kg vs Lbs? To me that makes no difference, really. But I sure do love Fahrenheit.

TL;DR - Fahrenheit has it's pros and cons but there are valuable and worthwhile reasons to use it.

There was an argument made that I can't remember the origin for that says pretty succinctly why I think Fahrenheit is a good measuring system and it went something like this:
While Celsius provides the necessary accuracy for scientific measurement, with regular numbers that make complete logical sense, Fahrenheit is not designed for such and shouldn't be considered for such. Fahrenheit's scale provides a more human experience of temperature - especially when considering weather and it's swinging temperature. For Celsius, this is hard to do as it is designed for scientific rigor and best made for computers as a result.
Celsius says freezing water happens at 0 and boiling it at 100, makes perfect sense. It measures how temperature messes with water, a good thing to point out. However, what's a good temperature to go out in the park for a stroll? Somewhere in the teens of the scale? Possibly in the twenties? Celsius is good for science, but the human experience of temperature is a bit more subjective.
What good temperature to go outside in with Fahrenheit? Well, while the experience of the individual might differ, it's likely in the range of 60-80 - with a tendency to cap it closer to the high 70s then stray into the 80s. is it below 60? You might want to dress a bit warmer. Meanwhile is the scale starts straying into the 90s or breaks 100 you know that it's likely to be uncomfortable. It makes sense for human intuition.
It's almost like a percentage scale in its application - you're 60% sure you can go out today or 100% sure you rather not. It's not great when talking about computers or science as you quickly find numbers that really lose meaning when Celsius can tell you with absolute confidence the relative positions of the temperature in accordance with common phenomena - relating everything to how water acts. Fahrenheit, however, is good for telling the weather.
In short, Celsius is the scale for science and computers, while Fahrenheit is the scale for humans who want to know whether they need a jacket or just a tshirt.

Unpopular opinion (outside of the U.S.): Fahrenheit is a better system of measurement than Celsius for casual usage. For laymen, temperature is most often used in relation to the human body, whether it be describing the ambient temperature of an environment, or an object someone is touching. With Fahrenheit, you can get a good descriptive sense at the tens place,  i.e. saying it will be "in the 50's today" gives a precise description of the feeling of the weather that is not possible with Celsius (the difference between 10°C and 20°C being the difference between 50°F and 68°F). Fahrenheit quickly and easily describes temperature in ways that matter most commonly, and with more precision as whole numbers than Celsius. The environment commonly reaches both 0°F and 100°F and intuitively correspond to very cold and very hot, but well within the scope of human experience. Plus, if you want precision for scientific purposes, just use Kelvin. Celsius is useless beyond the fact that so many people use it. It is the Sunk Cost Fallacy at a global scale. I think I might know why Americans have such a hard time dropping the Fahrenheit scale in exchange for the seemingly simpler Celsius.

The span of degrees between freezing and boiling in °F began as 60. It's divisible by 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 10, 12, 15, 20, 30, and 60.

By rounding and quadrupling his numbers, he wound up with a base 240 system. The factors of 240 are 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, 15, 16, 20, 24, 30, 40, 48, 60, 80, 120, 240.
There are 20 increments into which you can conveniently divide the Fahrenheit scale, as opposed to the 9 options Celsius offers: 1, 2, 4, 5, 10, 20, 25, 50, 100.
There are more than twice as many options in Fahrenheit before the use of decimals becomes necessary for the layman's daily use, and because we're all familiar was a base-60 time and geometry system, we're already primed to use a temperature system of this kind. We also have a base-12 system for dimensional measurement.

Even for those who aren't mathematically inclined, Fahrenheit lends itself well to daily use. Decimal systems are very convenient because we count using base-10. Base-60 systems are convenient because they're highly divisible. I don't think either is really superior. They set out to achieve the same task in different ways and both came up with clever ways to make the tracking of temperature convenient.

Personally, though, I'd like to see a system that puts 0° at absolute 0 and boiling point of water at 360°

Scientifically speaking, Centigrade is not based on a useful or neutral absolute measure because water’s boiling and freezing point varies with pressure. 100°C/212°F￼ is basically the boiling point in all European capital cities because they are situated around sea level so have an atmospheric pressure approximating 14.7 lbf/in2￼. But if you live in a high altitude capital city (common in Africa, South America and other parts of the world) then atmospheric pressure and thus water’s boiling point is lower (e.g. in Mexico City it’s 200°F (93°C)￼ or in Addis Ababa 198°F (92°C)￼). The video’s claim that Fahrenheit is “arbitrary” whilst Centigrade is not reflects I’m afraid an implicit bias to a Western (European) frame of reference, which is not scientific.

This is wrong in some respects.  Fahrenheit wanted his revised scale to cover most temperatures commonly experienced in 100 steps, to avoid fractions.  He set the zero at the coldest temperature he could achieve in a laboratory, and 100 at human body temperature.  He then noticed that the freezing and boiling points of water ended up being close to 180° apart.  He decided that 180 steps between two easily produced temperatures was convenient, so he defined them as 32°F and 212°F, exactly (at standard pressure).  This shifted the zero and 100 points slightly.  This explanation comes from Isaac Asimov, who was a PhD biochemist as well as a writer.

According to Encyclopædia Britannica, the scale of Fahrenheit was designed such that there are 180 degrees between the respective freezing and boiling points of water—a multiple of 60, just like Rømer's scale—yet it would seem as though this specific multiple of 60 would be the wrong one, because 180 / 60 = 3.

The most important point is that fahrenheit is relevant to temperatures humans typically experience in the world. In any part of the world that has four normal seasons (i.e. not the Bahama's eternal summer or north Russia's eternal winter) you will generally experience 0-10 degree weather in winter and 90-100 degree weather in summer. Any negative temperature below 0 (-18c) or triple-digit temperature above 100 (38c) is the extreme and will be dangerous without proper preventative measures.

Another much less significant advantage to F is that it is more than twice as fine as C, so the average person only ever needs to worry about whole number temperatures. European celcius thermostats almost always display and are set by half degrees (i.e. room temperature might be 21.5) whereas American fahrenheit thermostats never do (room temperature may be 70 or 71 but never 70.5).

Meanwhile literally the only argument I have ever heard ANYONE provide in support of celcius is that water freezes and boils at 0 and 100 degrees, which to me seems completely arbitrary and unimportant. Being big, pretty, clean numbers like how the metric is all based on multiples of 10 has absolutely no significance here because no one uses "kilodegrees" or "centidegrees" and (as far as I know) there is no conversion that is made prettier simply because of those set points.

Can you honestly think of any reason water boiling/freezing at 0 and 100 would ever matter? I mean, when do those numbers ever actually come up in your life? Nobody is measuring the temperature of their water and refusing to boil their pasta or brew their tea with 99c degree water... and icecubes are always at LEAST several degrees below 0c because ice/water that was exactly 0c would be trying to melt and freeze at the same time.

If there is any reason to use celcius which is actually useful on a day-to-day basis for the average human, I would genuinely like to know. Until I find such a reason that outweighs my first point, I am convinced it would be most efficient if everyone switched to Metric... AND Fahrenheit.

Both are arbitrary and can't be used for scientific calculations. Fahrenheit is most useful for the human experience of weather where 0F is a really cool temperature and 100F is a really hot temperature for a continental climate. The water cycle is irrelevant. Celsius is based around the water cycle, but only on earth at atmospheric pressure, at sea level. Its a difference in aesthetics as to which one is better because neither of them will work in any thermodynamic calculations, which is why Kelvin was invented and is the scale where 0 actually means zero as negative temperature can't actually exist in the universe. Every extraterrestrial civilization will know the concept of absolute zero but they will not have a concept of Fahrenheit or Celsius as the weather and water cycle on their planet could be completely different. 0C for water freezing and 100C for water turning to steam does not apply anywhere else in the universe unless there is another planet that is exactly like earth. Fahrenheit is used in the US primarily for weather on planet earth in climates where the majority of people live, which you could say it is perfectly suited to do as your daily weather has very little to do with the water cycle.

People create units for some sort of cultural and aesthetic reasoning all the time. The astronomical unit, lightyear, parsec, solar mass, earth mass are all units that are used for aesthetics as they are somewhat easy to understand and relate to without doing some sort of mental gymnastics to calculate how far some object is. You could use petametres which is roughly 9.4 petametres per light year, but astronomers don't bother using petametres in their communications. Likewise we don't use yottagrams to describe masses of planets, we use earth mass. Its easier to describe a planet as 312 earth masses rather than 1.9 million yottagrams.

Americans using Fahrenheit do so because of a cultural aesthetic for a scale which revolves around weather vs the water cycle. It is every bit as arbitrary as using Celsius. All of these units are defined by their SI values anyway, so using one or the other is a preference.

What's the obsession with measuring water temperature (which celsius is designed to do)? I mean - how often have you ever had to do that? Air temperature though (which fahrenheit is designed to measure) is a genuinely practical thing to measure and we do it daily; and since the human body is quite sensitive to small changes in temperature, the finer fahrenheit scale is helpful.  Basically, the briny-water thing was a back-design; the intention was to have the human body at 100 and boiling water at 200 degrees, so it made sense to find a basis for 0. So, they were imprecise 300 years ago. The same can easily be said of Celsius, regardless of hot outside being in the 30 to 40 range. I have lived with the Celsius scale my entire life, and as a result am fully accustomed to perceiving hot climates as being in the 30s.

Some people may be inclined to think that because Fahrenheit is broader in what it sets as 0 and 100, it offers a more precise scale. But because humans are not naturally attuned to perceiving fine gradients of temperature (we feel hot, we feel cold, and know they're different; the average person could not tell you the difference between 40 and 41 degrees Fahrenheit), the level of precision offered by Fahrenheit may not be necessary in every day life.

As for the notion that because Celsius is defined by the freezing and boiling points of water, it is not relevant to every day life, I could have sworn people deal with frozen or boiling water all the time. In every freezer you will find frozen water, so you have a rough gauge of how cold it is in the freezer, as it is when it is snowing or the lake/pond has frozen over. And with the boiling point of water, people have experience with that every time they turn the kettle on of put a pot of water on the stove to boil. The point is that frozen/boiling water affects people all the time, so it is perfectly acceptable for everyday use.

I can use both units, I prefer metric in the lab and imperial in my day to day life as the unites are more natural.
most imperial units are divisible by 2, 3, 4, and 6 while metric you have 2, 5, 10. you cannot equally divide a meter by 3, while a yard becomes a foot then a foot becomes 4 inches an inch becomes 4000 thou (not commonly used) but rulers have 16 intervals in an inch allowing for easier division.

For cooking it is more complicated but making multiples or divisions of a recipes is easier without decimals. a U.S. gallon is 4 quarts, a quart is 2 pints, a pint is 2 cups, a cup is 16 table spoons, a table spoon is 3 teaspoons. then you get the ones everyone has heard about but has no idea what they are, like a dash, pinch or smidgen (yes they are real)

The metric system is also harder to recreate. if i gave you a meter long rope and told you to divide it into the smallest equal units it would be almost impossible, you could fold it in half and show me where the 5 dm line then again for 250 cm was but you could not show me 1, 2, 3, or 4 dm along the rope. if i gave you a yard long rope you could fold it into thirds showing three feet, then one foot could be folded in half then half again and finally thirds and you could show my an individual inch. Temperature has similar constraints, with Celsius you could find boiling and freezing giving 0 and 100 you could divide that in half and show 50 then again for 25 but you could never show me 1, 5, or 10 degrees. With Fahrenheit set freezing at 32 and boiling at 212 for 180 degrees between, 180 goes to 90 then 30 then 10 then 5 while not 1 degree you would have 30 equal divisions to measure with instead of 4.

In the lab you 100% correct metric is better but outside while more accurate is less useful. if you were a carpenter ordering wood by the 1m would be impractical as you could never decide in three or 6 equal parts so you would order 120cm or a similar multiple. Ordering a drink by the volume say 500ml instead of taking a pint (473.176ml) for simplicity sake. cooking meals which would call for all ingredients to be weighed out individually instead of scooped in a volumetric container.

tl:dr both systems have there uses, no use fighting over it.

Derek, you should know that even in places where Celsius is common, it's not the /only/ temperature scale used. The temperature scales which are used are those which are /most appropriate/ for the given application.

eV (electron volts) - temperature scale (scaled by Boltzmann's constant) most appropriate for high energy physics, condensed matter physics, and most applications of statistical physics (where k_bT shows up) (room temperature is ~1/40 eV)

K (kelvin) - temperature scale most appropriate for most sciences

°C (celsius)- temperature scale most appropriate for applications involving liquid water, such as chemistry and cooking (as water is liquid between 0 °C and 100 °C)

°F (fahrenheit)- temperature scale most appropriate for applications involving weather, as the majority of weather falls between 0 °F and 100 °F

R (rankine)- not really appropriate for anything, because K does the same job and is more widely used

It's true that we could develop a better temperature scale which would be more appropriate for describing weather related phenomena, but if we're working with what we already have, what should be done is for everyone to use the temperature scale most appropriate for the application being considered.

There are excellent reasons for preferring most of the metric system of weights and measures to the Imperial system used in the USA - ease of mathematical manipulation and inter-relatedness being the two most important. But the Celsius scale is no better than the Fahrenheit scale in either of these regards. Mathematical manipulation is not generally an issue with temperature, and if it is, both scales are equally amenable. (The Fahrenheit scale has a 0 and a 100 degree mark just like Celsius). And the relationship of the scale to a single physical property (like the freezing point of water) is arbitrary and of little practical value. Might as well relate it to the temperature of a vole anus. So the advantages of metric weights and measures do not apply to the Celsius temperature scale. On the other hand, the Fahrenheit scale has finer whole-number gradations than the Celsius scale and so is more precise in common usage.

In short, while the USA should (but probably won't) convert to most of the metric weights and measures, it is the rest of the world that should convert to the Fahrenheit scale.

To be really fair, all measuring schemes are completely arbitrary and there's nothing special about Celsius or metric aside from wide adoption. Which, admittedly, is reason enough to encourage adoption in places that don't use it.

The way I understand Fahrenheit's development of his scale went like this: Using a Hg thermometer, the CDE point, cold day in Europe, set 0°. Using the same thermometer, the freezing point of water was marked so was the boiling point of water. With three marks on the thermometer, all that was needed was the graduations. Fahrenheit viewed the circle as a perfect geometric shape so he used it as a model. Much like latitude and longitude, he placed 180 spaces (degrees) between the freezing point and boiling point. This lead to 0° F for CDE, 32° F for freezing point and 212° F for the boiling point.

There is no reason for the average US citizen to switch to metric, just like there is no reason for the average citizen of the EU to use the imperial system.

1) Most US citizens only rarely interact with metric users, so they do not have to convert between the two systems.

2) The metric system is just as arbitrary as the imperial system. Why should a meter be some fraction of the length of a longitude line? It is just as weird as saying that a foot should be the length of some famous guy's foot. In fact, at least most people have feet, so if they did not have a measuring device they could still measure about how many feet something is without having to compute the length of a longitude line first.

3) The strength of the metric system is the ability to convert between units of the same dimension, but no one ever needs to do that in the imperial system. No one ever has a measurement in feet and needs to know what fraction of a mile it is.

4) The metric system still has weird conversions, like between seconds, minutes, and hours, or between calories and joules, or between atmospheres, pascals, and millimeters of mercury, so if it were desirable to switch to a system that has easy conversions between units of the same measure, then we would have to replace the metric system with a system that has multiples of ten conversions for units of time, energy, and pressure.

On the Fahrenheit scale however, 0 degrees is very cold, and you can know with certainty that you're going to need a jacket if you're going to be outside for any length of time; whereas 100 degrees is very hot, and you can know with certainty that it's probably best to spend the day either in the pool or inside. So many people say that Celsius is objectively better when truly it's only advantage is that it's already widely used. The advantage of the metric system is that everything is broken up into units of ten, whereas in the imperial system they are broken up into units of varying amounts that are hard to keep track of. But you don't do that with temperature, there is no special name for 1000 degrees Celsius like there is for 1000 meters. The only difference between Celsius and Fahrenheit is the size of their units and where they put zero. It may seem to make no sense, but Fahrenheit is actually really good for weather reporting. Due to the fact that it's more precise (a 10 degree interval in Celsius equates to an almost 20 degree interval in Fahrenheit), the range of temperatures that occur naturally in temperate regions covers the entire 0-100 of the Fahrenheit scale. You can also describe the temperature in terms of "in the 40s," "in the upper 70s," "low 50s," etc. And although this is purely coincidental, 0 and 100 act as sorts of endpoints of the scale when used in weather reporting. In many parts of the United States, 0 Fahrenheit is a very low temperature for a winter day, and likewise 100 is a very high temperature for a summer day. This depends on region of course. As an added bonus, many parts of the United States and Europe have year-round average temperatures of about 50 degrees Fahrenheit, and (coincidentally of course) 50 is the midpoint of the scale. The only downside I see to using Fahrenheit in weather reporting is the fact that freezing is 32 instead of 0, but this really isn't a big deal. Is the number 32 really that difficult to memorize? Keep in mind that Celsius (along with Kelvin) is already used for scientific purposes in the US, as it rightfully should be.
